Award.AwardTitle: Resonant Cavity Photodetectors using thin GaInAs/GaAsSb Quantum wells

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to develop mid-infrared photodetectors using indium phosphide-based materials for applications where high sensitivity and near-room temperature operation are desired. These materials provides advantages including the use of compressive and tensile strained materials for flexible device design options and mature wafer foundry capabilities for processing InP-based structures. This program is transformative in that it couples mid-infrared optoelectronics to a technology platform that has been well developed in industry but does not currently allow use of this wavelength range.

The intellectual merit is to use a resonant-cavity approach that combines a thin, strained quantum well absorption region with high-reflectivity mirrors. Experiments have shown that these quantum wells can absorb light beyond 3000 nm at room temperature. The addition of strain with a novel strain compensation approach will allow an extension of the detection wavelength. The use of a resonant cavity decouples the optical absorption length and physical thicknesses of the quantum wells leading to both higher quantum efficiency and lower dark currents.

The broader impacts of this program are to create a technology that can have a positive influence on society through its use in both military and civilian applications. In addition, this program focuses on two main categories for research/education integration: recruiting a talented undergraduate to pursue research with the goal of encouraging him or her to pursue graduate studies and the development of educational materials which can be used to educate first-year engineering students on the societal benefits of this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Light with a wavelength beyond what our eyes can “see” (called the infrared regime) are important for many applications. This is due to many factors: a transmission window in the Earth’s atmosphere, the fact that many organic compounds (e.g., CO, CH4, NH3, N2O, SO2 and HNO3) absorb light in this wavelength range, and background radiance including night glow (approximately 1.7 to 2 mm) and blackbody self-emission (approximately 2 to 2.5 mm) are much stronger than airglow, which is important for imaging in proton starve environments. 

In previous work we had developed GaInAs/GaAsSb quantum wells for the infrared detection on InP.  Using an InP-based platform provided advantages such as flexible device design options, mature wafer foundry capabilities for processing InP-based structures, and the ability to couple infrared optoelectronics to a technology platform that has been well developed in industry but does not currently allow use of this wavelength range.  One of the challenges of this approach was a coupling of light absorption and carrier collection (important for device efficiency); when we created structures to increase light absorption, carrier collection would decrease and vice versa (see Figure 1).

Our main goal in this program was to create and demonstrate structures that decoupled light absorption and carrier collection.  The approach we used was a waveguide structure (see Figure 2).  In this case, the light absorption occurs parallel to the device structure while carrier collection occurs perpendicular. 

To date, we have accomplished the following performance in these devices (Figures 3-5):

  • dark currents as low as 100 nA at -2V
  • an external responsivity as  high as 0.27 A/W at 2 µm and 0.3 A/W at 1.55 µm
  • a 3 dB bandwidth of 3.5 GHz at 2 µm

These are comparable to competing technologies.  These results have also lead to a collaboration with the University of New Mexico to continue to extend this work for communication applications around 2 mm and three publications (1 under review).
